content.content: TL;DR I have been in favor of 0-PSM-fees to provide a hardened peg since the introduction of the PSM. I am now convinced that this was a mistake as this policy removes the incentive for normal vault holders to arbitrage on depegging and by that just leaving the leverage-usecase for vault holders. As the appetite for leveraging crypto is not very strong, we have reached a stablecoin ratio of ~80% recently - turning DAI more and more into a USDC-wrapper.  Rethinking PSM-fees For those not having an idea what PSMs are - here is a great summary. I’d like to focus on the two parameters defining the fees:   tin - the percentage fee applied when trading a stablecoin (USDC, GUSD, USDP) in exchange for DAI  tout the percentage fee applied when trading DAI against a stablecoin.  Trading DAI back to another stablecoin is of course only possible if there is enough of it deposited on our side - which is not too much of an issue as we have 3.3B of USDC and almost 500 MM of USDP in our PSMs. Both parameters are set to 0, allowing trades into both directions without any conversion fees. Last changes on tin: Signal Request, Onchain Poll, Executive vote - last changes on tout: Signal Request, Onchain Poll, Executive Vote As soon as DAI is depegging to the north - let’s say trading at $ 1.01 - anyone can easily arb this by converting their USDC to DAI and selling it with a premium. As there is no fee on our side, this does happen really quickly. If we would have a fee of 1%, using the PSM would only be profitable, if the price of DAI is > $1.01. Between $1.00 and $1.01 the only way to arb it is to mint DAI using real collateral. As we have zero fees on the PSM, the only use case for native crypto vaults is to leverage your collateral - the appetite for leveraging crypto collateral seems to be at an all time low, the only metric growing on DAI is the stablecoin-ratio (currently at a record 80%). Vault usage is going down more and more. If this trend continues DAI will (slowly) turn into a stablecoin wrapper. If we would increase the tin just a bit, we could re-enable the arbitrage use case for crypto-vault holders. This will very likely not happen really quickly, as there is a lot of e.g. DAIUSDC liquidity on other platforms like curve and uniswap that will be used first. But over time, it will be attractive again to arb the peg just by using crypto vaults again and the PSM will remain as a last-resort peg-stability-enforcer. Increasing the spread also opens up the market for liquidity outside of the Maker Protocol, right now since you can trade 1:1 we’re the primary market for DAI/USDC trades. By opening a window between 1 and 1.01 we’re allowing the market to find a price between there.  Next steps I’d like to use this thread to gauge sentiment about increasing the tin again - if successful I will start a Signal Request on that topic in a couple of days. I would be happy to get comments, additional perspectives and also roasting if this idea is stupid. Moving away from 0-fee PSMs will likely have some effects that should be taken into consideration: what is the impact on RWA, GUNI… Happy to hear your thoughts

content.content: The following opinions my own and do not represent PECU Setting the PSM fees to zero has played out pretty much exactly the way that many of us had predicted. Michael from Curve warned even before the PSM was implemented that market price discovery for Dai is necessary and that setting the fees to 1:1 would cause “empty shelves” in secondary markets by attempting to price fix at the protocol level. I warned prior to the imposition of the zero fee tin that Maker holders would expect to take on many multiples more stables than we had backing Dai, and that’s indeed what has happened, to the point where we’re at a laughable 80% stablecoin backing for Dai. By attempting to stomp down the market premium for Dai we’ve disincentivized vault usage generally, which is and should be the protocol’s bread and butter as sticky revenue. By not allowing the market to price in a premium to Dai when it is in demand there is less incentive to generate new Dai via collateral vaults. Without the ability to apply variable rates to sop up Dai on the downside of the peg none of the other strategic money games work. Swapping bonds with Circle on the backend is not an interesting defi primitive nor is it one that I think people will get excited to support Maker over. The original desire for reducing the fees to zero apparently stemmed from a desire to ensure Dai could be purchased at $1 by Dai holders. This is not something we should optimize for. The MakerDAO White Paper describes Dai as “collateral-backed cryptocurrency soft-pegged to the US Dollar.” This soft-peg is critically important to the long-term stability of the token as the price fluctuates to represent market sentiment. High Dai price means high demand, and encourages Dai generation, it also discourages and should discourage repayments, which would take Dai out of circulation. Conversely, Dai below peg discourages new vaults and means that borrowers can buy Dai at a discount and repay debt, thus reducing supply and driving the price up. At scale, we can expect that by allowing these market incentives to play out as intended market participants will naturally play both sides of the peg and keep the token price on track. By removing this critical market signal we’ve eliminated the ability for market participants to grow in a healthy and sustainable way. Instead, we’ve provided nominal Dai price stability at the cost of existential risk to the protocol without any reward to MKR holders. It’s time to declare this experiment with zero fees a failure and begin to allow the protocol to heal by embracing the innate incentives of the system. The PSM in and of itself is a compromise to those incentives, but in the long term, a PSM with zero fees interferes too much with the systemic feedback mechanisms that keep the system upright.

content.content: IMO the most important aspect of Dai is that it is reliable money the average person can trust with their savings and use in their every day life. Ideally you should be able to only use Dai as your preferred form money or savings, Dai shouldn’t have to be some secondary, strange asset that can’t be used unless you also have some other “real” money. In that context anything other than 0 fee PSM makes no sense. What kind of money charges you a fee for trying to spend it or withdraw it? We would simply be shutting the door on adoption and pushing people to stay with fiat or centralized systems. Even if we haven’t figured out the collateral yet, we will be able to in the future… but it will only matter if people actually use Dai. In terms of mainstream adoption, nobody, absolutely nobody, cares about USDC or decentralization. That’s something we have to sneak in once they’ve adopted Dai for other reasons. Decentralization isn’t a value proposition, it’s a kind of charity or responsibility to society that we will not be rewarded for providing - just like Clean Money, sustainability, and other forms of public good that Maker can revolutionize if it reaches its full potential, it falls entirely on us to deliver in ways that don’t inconvenience the users.

content.content: No, but if we raise them unpredictably or create an expectation that they could raise unpredictably, I think we can expect more outflows
Revenues will eventually be solved by getting access to treasury yields. Getting back market share of crypto-native assets is important, but we shouldn’t care so much about the SF yields.

I actually looked at this question back of the envelope for G-UNI DAI/USDC 1bps vaults, when rates went from 25 bps to 5bps, quite a deep cut. Again just really rough calculations here but the tldr is that rate cuts that are too deep effectively net lose revenue to the system and can’t be recovered easily, so more gentle changes may be more appropriate. However, more research on other vaults and over other time-frames is necessary to extend this conclusion.  image1312×235 10.4 KB  The price elasticity of this vault for this rate shock is on the order of -2.5. This move effectively lost Maker ca. 200k in annualized revenues as the increase in borrowing demand did not compensate for the decrease in rates. Furthermore, now that we are at the ‘bottom’ on rates as it were, we are stuck. Raising rates back to 25bps would flatten demand to 0. If we were to increase even 1bp we would lose another 100k in annualized revenues. All else being equal a more suitable cut would have been from 25bps to 17.5bps, which would have actually increased annualized revenues by 100k. This model suggests actually cutting from 5bps by another 1.5bps to 3.5 to pump demand by more than the decline in rates. Again this is just a toy model, not worth its salt for proper rate recommendations. But gentle step-changes are an interesting hypothesis worth exploring further and a heuristic that could be worth bearing in mind when it comes to rate-setting, particularly in a ‘panic’ as we try and shore up demand as best we can.

content.content: This may be true if we’re moving toward a future where PSMs are always going to be as large as they are now.  But I think there is a shared vision out there of a DAI safely backed by all kinds of collateral not under the control of any one party or jurisdiction.  If this were ever able to happen, the PSMs would naturally shrink in comparison to these other collateral types.  We are where we are simply because demand for crypto backed loans has disappeared. The PSMs as they are now provide the clearest and simplest visibility into demand for holding DAI and allows the protocol to respond quickly if we were to see this demand flag.  We should not take these large PSMs for granted and be grateful that demand to hold DAI has not disappeared in the same way lending demand has.  If the fed hikes a little bit more, do not be surprised if we start seeing outflows again…  Centralization to stablecoin issuers is a risk and obviously against the ethos of MKR but this bear market is not done.  So until revenues are increasing and profitability is clear, we must be careful not to weaken the position of the protocol in the quest to address these existential risks.

content.content: brianmcmichael:  High Dai price means high demand, and encourages Dai generation, it also discourages and should discourage repayments, which would take Dai out of circulation.   Unfortunately I don’t think the incentives really play out like this in practice. Without PSMs (or with wider spreads), vault users face a lot of uncertainty about their total cost of borrowing, particularly over shorter time periods. So while users may have some theoretical profit opportunities if DAI price is eg. $1.005, they must also consider the risk that premium blows out to $1.01 (or even higher) at the time they want to repay. And those specifically targeting these arb opportunities would likely want to use higher leverage (to make the trade capital efficient enough to generate meaningful profits), but this increases risk of forced closing during a price spike. I’d expect greater DAI price volatility to discourage ETH vault usage on net as most just want a safe, predictable, low cost way to leverage their holdings and are not interested in seeking profit by arbing the peg.

content.content: Yesterday’s Gov and risk call had a lively chat about this topic. Signalling then adding a fee change might not be the best next step, but it will likely be one of the outcomes. More importantly, the question we’re really asking is: do we want to encourage vault opening (revenues) or market parity through liquidity? (which we also don’t get paid for) They are intrinsically linked, but my hunch is that @brianmcmichael  is more correct, other platforms exist that are far more efficient for arbing peg discrepancies.  I took this note yesterday (forgive me @rema)  “What we could do, is set hard peg limits higher than 1:1, at like 1-3% tin and have some of both worlds; assurance that peg wont spike and this arbing game of soft peg mechanisms”  Understanding these questions via polls would be helpful:  What level of backing is the community comfortable backing DAI ? 30, 40, 50, 60 % ? 0 ? Should we turn on tin fees above that level? What amount of USDC on the books is needed for predictable RWA generation and management? What are the hard peg limits?  I think these parameters should be on the table at the MOMC tbh. In conjunction with understanding community sentiment we can slowly unwind what isn’t necessary, send a signal that we don’t want to make a market above a certain level, and put the assets to work when we have them above an acceptable amount. Ancillary questions:  How do we not rug GUNI vaults? Is there something creative we can do working with Curve etc.?
